Introduction

To  control  infection  it  is  important  to  minimise,  reduce  and  eliminate  potential environmental contamination. This includes equipment used in the treatment and care of  patients.  Standard  precautions  indicate  that  ALL  blood  and  bodily  fluids  are potentially infectious, posing a risk of cross infection to patients and staff
Purpose
This document provides guidance for
All staff
This  policy  provides  instruction  on  the  procedures  which  should  be  taken following spillage of blood, other bodily fluids and known contaminated material.

data.text: Role & Responsibilities within the Trust

The Site Infection Prevention and Control Committees (IPCC) are responsible for the review of this policy at least every two years, but more frequently if there are changes to Infection Prevention and Control Legislation or guidance.
The Chief Executive has overall responsibility for the implementation of this policy. The Chief Executive delegates this responsibility to the Director for Infection Prevention and Control.
The Director for Infection Prevention and Control (DIPC) has the responsibility to ensure there are adequate resources available to manage infection prevention and control within the Trust
Employees have the responsibility to:
Adhere to this policy and procedures
Attend relevant training as appropriate to their individual role
Participate in any relevant audit as part of the Infection Prevention and Control Audit Programme
Identify to their line manager any problems or failings associated with the management of spillages of biological fluids
Promptly report all incidents concerning the risks or exposure to spillages of blood and bodily fluids in accordance with the Trust's Incident Reporting Policy
Infection Prevention and Control Team (IPCT) responsibilities are to:
Promote evidence based infection prevention and control practices in line with Trust policies
Be responsible for the production of the policy and management procedures
Occupational Health Department have responsibility to:
Screen and monitor staff as clinically necessary
Appropriate management of care of staff members
Liaise with the IPCT as and when required
The Grounds Team are responsible for:
The clean-up of body fluids outside of hospital buildings/hospital grounds
Spillages
Responsibility for dealing with spillages of bodily fluids
Wards and Departments- Healthcare workers first clean, Domestic staff – second clean
Main entrance, main corridors, communal areas outside wards and departments- contact Cleaning Response Team (CRT) via Switchboard

In the event of contamination of the environment with potentially infectious material, including blood, urine, faeces and vomit, you should contact the Infection Prevention and Control Department who can advise on safe practice. If specimens are dropped or broken, or  waste  body  fluids  are in  evidence,  the  following  procedure  should be immediately carried out by clinical staff.
Locate the Clinell spillage pack (see below)

Put the soiled wipe back into the bag
Remove the disinfectant wipe from the sachet
Clean the spill in an ‘S' shaped motion from clean to dirty area, as per Spillage kit instructions.
Put the soiled wipe and empty sachet back into the pack
Dispose of the pack into orange clinical waste bag
Wash and dry your hands thoroughly
It is the responsibility of the person involved in cleaning the spillage to ensure that the spillage kit is replaced immediately.

data.text: If the spillage involved a clinical specimen, the identity of the patient should be established and the relevant doctor or nurse informed of the incident as soon as possible.
Major Spillage
A major spillage can be defined as a large spillage of body fluids and/or sewage.
If a major spillage occurs, the person finding the spillage must inform the Clinical Site Manager immediately.
The individual finding the spillage should not leave the area where the spillage occurred and should prevent admittance to the area until the Containment Team are in attendance.
Inform the Clinical Site Manager who will coordinate the process of managing a major spillage.
Containment Team consists of the following personnel:
The Senior Maintenance Manager
Domestic Service Manager or Deputy
Infection Prevention & Control Nurse
Portering Manager or Deputy
The porters will deliver the major spillage kit to the area concerned
Action
7.1.1 Once the cause of the spillage has been rectified, the area can be cleaned by relevantly trained domestic staff.

7.1.2 Caution must be exercised when dealing with large spillages of urine, e.g. under bed spills from urine bottles in the immediate patient area. There may be a release of chlorine which, although harmless, may cause temporary discomfort to the patient who is suffering from an existing chest condition, especially where ventilation is limited. The patient should be temporarily excluded from the area until the spillage is cleaned up.
Put on any relevant PPE dependant on size of spillage (disposable gloves, apron, eye protection if there is likely to be splashing and wellington boots)
Prepare the DIFF-X solution in 5 litres of cold NOT HOT, water
Mop the surface with the solution and leave to dry
Discard any unused solution
Use disposable cloths to wipe down any furniture or equipment that has been exposed to the spillage
Disposable yellow mops to be used and yellow buckets should be cleaned following use. Do not use Vileda micro fibre to clean up major spillages
Discard used disposable cloths into a tagged orange clinical waste bag for incineration
Disposable Gloves and apron should be discarded into a tagged orange clinical waste bag.
Hands must be thoroughly washed and dried
Complete a Datix Incident Form
Carpets and Soft furnishings
7.2.1  Carpets and soft furnishings are not recommended in clinical areas. Where they are present, deep cleaning is recommended immediately following spills
Training Requirements
All trust staff must undertake mandatory infection training and attend regular updates as required.

data.text: Approval and Implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Infection Prevention and Control Committee, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve MSE  Policies.  These  will  then  be  forwarded  to  the  Document  control  team  for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It  is  the  author's  responsibility  to  inform  the  Director  of  Harm  Free  Care  of  the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
